column2775: Cities' commitments vary both by number of commitments and type of commitments. When cities join the Cities Race to Resilience, they pledge their support to integrate climate change adaptation and resilience in all aspects of urban planning and undertake a community-wide climate risk and vulnerability assessment. Then they plan to use available knowledge and scientific evidence, including data and spatial analysis, for decision-making and action, and outline interim targets and milestones as part of a long-term commitment for citywide action. Each city then immediately proceeds to taking action by committing to at least one of the 64 resilience actions as listed on www.citiesracetoresilience.org by COP27. They then report each of these commitments by COP26 - and progress annually thereafter, to an existing or recommended reporting platform. Please note, we do not currently know which commitments for each city are a) already being undertaken, b) complete, or c) have not yet begun. We will not know until all our city's have completed their annual reporting progress. Therefore, the sections below have been left blank.
column2786: Please note, we do not currently know which commitments (actions) for each city are   a) already being undertaken,   b) complete, or   c) have not yet begun.   We will not know until all our city's have completed their annual reporting progress. Therefore, this part of the reporting tool is incomplete.

column2775: Arsht-Rock and EHRA build individual and city resilience to extreme heat through the following strategies:      Targeted communications, warning systems, and actionable strategies: Arsht-Rock and the Extreme Heat Resilience Alliance (EHRA) develop tools that cities and other jurisdictions can use to clearly and evocatively message the risks and solutions of extreme heat to their populations and engage stakeholders, including categorizing and naming heatwaves. For example, the Heat Action Platform, launched by Arsht-Rock alongside several partners at the World Economic Forum in May 2022, is intended to provide governments and ficial institutions with a resource with which to plan for the risks and impacts of heat.           Additionally, in 2021, Arsht-Rock launched a public campaign for cities to announce the start of dangerous hot weather (#HeatSeason), similar to how hurricanes and other natural disasters are communicated.  The Heat Season campaign includes public communications and educational graphics for social media that highlight the risk of heat and how people can stay safe during heat waves.           Mobilize global experts, public leaders, and stakeholders in the Extreme Heat Resilience Alliance to accelerate implementation: Arsht-Rock connects EHRA and local, regional, and national leaders to co-create policies and implement projects which help people become more heat resilient, with a focus on vulnerable communities.          For example, Arsht-Rock works with its core partner cities and organizations to unify the response to heat by appointing Chief Heat Officers, local officials focused on the risks and impacts of heat on their city residents. Chief Heat Officers in Miami-Dade County, USA, Athens, Greece, Monterrey, Mexico, Santiago, Chile, Freetown, Sierra Leone, and institutionalized within UN-Habitat lead the development and implementation of heat resilience policies and programs that meet the unique needs of their community.          Arsht-Rock also partners with and works in other cities, including Seville, Spain, and Chennai, India on other projects.          Build the evidence base for action: Arsht-Rock and EHRA work with global experts to quantify the economic and social consequences of extreme heat to cities and other jurisdictions, informing and inspiring leaders to act. Arsht-Rock and EHRA partnered with Vivid Economics to assess the impacts of heat on specific sectors and segments of the US population, catalyzing policy and investment that reduces the risks and costs resulting from the effects of heat. Arsht-Rock and EHRA are now working with Vivid on a 13-city global analysis to be released in Summer 2022.           Create the conditions that bring heat resilience solutions to scale: Arsht-Rock and EHRA are developing the tools, evaluation methods, and fice and insurance approaches that make heat resilience solutions implementable at a global scale.

column5: Restoring Landscapes and Livelihoods in Africa - Climate Asset Management Program
column17: Nature-based solutions to reduce risks

column174: Heat stress - lives & livelihoods combined; Extreme heat; Extreme cold; Snow and ice; Drought (agriculture focus); Water stress (rural focus)
column2775: The Programme is to improve livelihoods, food security and resilience to climate change through restoring ecosystem services in six countries in Africa, which aims  to restore  the  land  and  livelihoods  of  XXX small-scale farming households, covering an area of approximately XXXX hectares. The programme will  enable men  and  female farmers to  adopt  truly  innovative but proven methods for buffering crop production from drought and temperature stresses and increasing crop and livestock yields in the face of these stresses.      The underlining strategy of diversifying agricultural landscape through planting various climate-resilient types of crop and tree species will eventually minimise risks and stabilise yields over time. The programme will implement context-specific, evidence-driven, practice-oriented solutions and approaches to support the purposeful identification, selection, plantation and management of high-value fruit crops and trees in agricultural systems in the selected woredas. Using an Ecosystem-Based Adaptation (EBA) approach, this nature-based solution that harnesses biodiversity and ecosystem services will reduce vulnerability and build resilience to climate change. This approach involves the conservation, sustainable management and restoration of ecosystems which directly help people adapt to the impact of climate change. Therefore, EBA uses biodiversity and ecosystem services as part of an overall adaptation strategy to help households and communities adapt to the negative effects of climate change at local and national levels.

column2775: Restoring mangroves to cover at least half of all recent loss:  Over 1,100,000 ha of mangroves have been lost since 1996, the year that sets the baseline for our definition of “recent” loss, however not all of these are restorable due to erosion or urbanisation. It is estimated that 818,300 ha of mangroves are considered “restorable” and the goal seeks to restore half of this area by 2030. This is a deeply ambitious goal. Although the target does not include areas which would be near-impossible to restore, the “restorability” even of the remaining areas is likely to be highly variable. Assuming science-based restoration practices are employed and result in long-lasting restoration restoring half of recent loss would be 410,000 ha by 2030 (~51k ha a year).     Mangroves provide incredible coastal protection benefits – securing lives, infrastructure and economic security. The global values of annual flood risk reduction for 15 million people and over $65 billion worth of property ( give some indication of how such values play out, although current models are insufficient to model more exact values from specific locations or restoration actions.GMA scientists are working to calculate estimate values that our own interventions through 2030 could have.

column5: Halt loss of 16,800 ha of mangrove ecosystems by 2030

column2775: Reduce net mangrove losses driven by direct human actions to zero. Rates of mangrove loss appear to have slowed in recent decades, and it is an opportune moment to set the challenge to halt further losses. While we can aspire to halt all losses, this target refers to direct, and therefore manageable, human driven loss. However, recognising that mangroves are dynamic ecosystems, we acknowledge the possibility of making further gains as mangroves naturally colonise new locations. Any such gains should be seen to offer additionality to the gains made by halting losses of remaining cover.  Over the last decade to 2020, ~ 60,000 ha were lost, and we can estimate that 37,300 ha of this was due to direct human impacts. To bring such losses to zero by 2030 we need to start to reduce loss rates from now. Assuming a linear rate of reduction in human driven losses this would save approximately 16,800 ha by the end of 2030 compared to business as usual.     Mangroves provide incredible coastal protection benefits – securing lives, infrastructure and economic security. The global values of annual flood risk reduction for 15 million people and over $65 billion worth of property ( give some indication of how such values play out, although current models are insufficient to model more exact values from specific locations or restoration actions.GMA scientists are working to calculate estimate values that our own interventions through 2030 could have.

column2775: Doubling protection of mangroves globally would ensure long-term protection is increased from 40% to 80% of remaining mangroves.    With 41% of the world’s mangroves currently in protected areas, mangroves are already well covered compared to many other ecosystems. However, fundamental to lasting reduction of loss and restoration efforts is that those efforts don’t get reversed through the incorporation of mangroves into permanent forms of protection. These include traditional protected areas, but also Other Effective Area-based Conservation Measures (OECMs), which could encompass indigenous lands and areas of sustainable use where mangroves are protected from clear-felling and conversion. Given the current global mangrove area and what is already protected, the GMA aims to secure a further 6,100,000 ha under conservation measures.    Mangroves provide incredible coastal protection benefits – securing lives, infrastructure and economic security. The global values of annual flood risk reduction for 15 million people and over $65 billion worth of property ( give some indication of how such values play out, although current models are insufficient to model more exact values from specific locations or restoration actions.GMA scientists are working to calculate estimate values that our own interventions through 2030 could have.

column2775: An estimated 58% of Latin America’s climate-warming greenhouse emissions comes from land use, land use change, and forestry. When people cut down forests and damage ecosystems, the climate, biodiversity, and local people suffer.    Already, more than 40% of forests in Latin America and the Caribbean have been completely deforested or degraded. The region contains some of the most ecologically valuable forest ecosystems in the world, but 20% of forest lands (nearly 350 million ha) have been completely deforested and a further 20% (300 million ha) badly degraded. Large-scale and small-scale agriculture, infrastructure, and mining are the primary drivers of this change – and source of carbon emissions.    Why should people invest in restoring all of that land? It presents a special opportunity to shift the region’s landscapes from a carbon source to a carbon sink and to decarbonize the region’s economies. And because Latin America is home to an estimated 50% of the world’s biodiversity, protecting and restoring forests, wetlands, and other landscapes is key to protecting rare flora and fauna.    Healthy landscapes are also the lynchpin of the region’s agricultural sector, which represents an estimated 13% of global food and fiber trade. Sustainable agricultural and forestry practices – which can add up to $1,140 in value to a hectare of restored land – can support the growing demand for commodities and create jobs while maintaining and expanding forest cover. They can also help communities on the front line of climate change adapt to warming temperatures and extreme weather.    Initiative 20x20 partners are embracing that vision of a restored future by leading programs centered on six key techniques. In forests, reforestation (natural and assisted) and avoiding degradation and deforestation help bring ecological functionality to entire landscapes, protect biodiversity, and store carbon. In agricultural areas, the initiative works to boost crop yields while protecting water sources and soil health through agroforestry (trees on farms), silvopasture (trees on pasture), sustainable grassland management, and other low-carbon farming techniques.

column2775: The hypothesis is that ficial institutions will act as agents of change in transforming smallholder production towards NBS systems based on proven attractive risk adjusted returns. The theory of change is that by understanding the economic benefits of NbS, FIs catering to the most vulnerable will autonomously develop and promote commercial incentives to realize and fice NbS investments at commercial rates. Comprehensive Monitoring, Evaluation and Reporting (MRV) systems in ficial institutions enable statistical validation of most successful NbS: Ecosystem deterioration and climate change pose real risks to agricultural production. NbS are hence a risk mitigation strategy. The implementation of NbS   therefore enables lower loan defaults and loan loss provisions of ficial institutions while increased purchasing power, investment and payment capacity of small farmers will enhance attractiveness of the segment, its resilience and access to fice.

column2775: As part of the Climakers' initiative, we have gathered a number of best practices for increasing resilience and responding to the threats posed by climate change. The Climakers Alliance has developed a set of guidelines for a farmer driven climate change agenda, presented and launched at COP26. Elaborated by THE CLIMAKERS scientific partner CGIAR Research Program on Climate Change, Agriculture, and Food Security (CCAFS), and validated by the farmers in THE CLIMAKERS Alliance, these guidelines are conceived and designed as an “NDCs Toolkit” for policymakers on how to successfully integrate agriculture into the national fulfilment of the Paris Agreement, based on the best practices that farmers worldwide are already implementing to mitigate and adapt to climate change. These guidelines explore three   interrelated questions and outline some critical topics and action areas to help inform the national and global decision-making process. The first focuses on analysing the context and linkage between agriculture and climate change, revealing insights into potential  actions for achieving Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) and National Adaptation Plans (NAPs) goals. The second question tackles the necessity to integrate a holistic approach in decision-making processes to lead to a better and deeper understanding of local bottlenecks and barriers to adopting adaptation and mitigation   actions. Finally, the last one aims to ensure that the decisions made will be sustainable over the long run.   Before the publication and finalization of the guidelines, a first draft has been presented and shared among the members of the Alliance to in order to receive feedback and provide inputs and comments that have been integrated with the prepared guidelines presented   by CCAFS. WFO has worked closely with CCAFS to ensure that all practices received from the farmers were taken under consideration and validated accordingly by CCAFS   Scientists.
column2781: 1)Consultations carried out by Climakers to generate data from farmers; 2) Engagements with national governments and international processes on  incorporating farmers into policy making processes; 3) Climakers guidelines for a farmer driven climate change agenda

column2775: Resilience Hubs are community-serving facilities augmented to support residents, coordinate communication, distribute resources, and reduce carbon pollution while enhancing quality of life. Hubs provide an opportunity to effectively work at the nexus of community resilience, emergency management, climate change mitigation, and social equity while providing opportunities for communities to become more self-determining, socially connected, and successful before, during, and after disruptions.    Resilience Hubs are flexible both in their application and design. Sites are as diverse as the communities they serve.  Hubs typically require enhancements and upgrades that improve their capacity to provide service in all three operating conditions (everyday, disruption, and recovery). Upgrades can range in complexity and cost. This website and the USDN Guide to Developing Resilience Hubs provide guidance for developing a Resilience Hub in your community.    Resilience Hubs are like snowflakes, no two are alike. The core components of a Resilience Hub are intended to provide a frame for a human-centric approach to Resilience Hub implementation, but each community will have different sets of goals and priorities.    Resilience Hubs are built out around five foundational areas. Excluding any of these areas , or focusing solely on hard infrastructure components such as solar power and site weatherization, for example, runs the risk of putting hazards over humans and bypassing components fundamental to enhancing wellbeing day-to-day and growing community adaptive capacity. To optimize community outcomes, a holistic approach is key.
column2781: We have 110 member communities committed. We work in three Tiers (intro, design/planning, implementation). We support both a Community of Practice and Hubs directly
column2783: Hubs range in $$ needed for implementation. Some are upgrades that require $1 million and others are full new sites that require closer to $20 million
column2784: Currently we provide grants, resources and support for acquisition of funding for projects. This amount ranges throughout the year

column2775: The ARA Tracking, Learning and Sharing work is helping ARA members to share their journeys on progressing towards action and goal statements linked to the Adaptation Research for Impact principles and the ARA Theory of Change. So far 20 organisations have put forward actions. In addition 45 organisations are sharing learning on how they are bridging the gap between adaptation research and action on the ground. Since there are overlaps in members we will use 45 organisations as the direct beneficiary goal.
column2781: 2 publications will synthesis the shared learning on Bridging adaptation research and action and Understanding Climate risks.
column2786: We considered measuring at individual level but in the end would not have been able to provide the granular detail on this as we dont ask our members for this data (where they live, age, disability etc). On companies level though our actions are not considered resilience building as per R2R definitions (not service delivery etc). It would be good to find a way to reflect the benefits of learning and sharing and how this influences companies (e.g. adding selection criteria for southern leadership).

column5: Global South Talent Pool
column16: Surfacing, acknowledge and building capacities to support young experts from the Global South
column17: Surfacing, acknowledge and building capacities to support young experts from the Global South
column212: Africa; Asia; Latin America and the Caribbean; Oceania
column2775: The coalition has three functions: Collaborate, Connect and Apply. The functions are interrelated, but each has specific objectives and activities. Under the collaborate function, the coalition implements phased and strategic capacity-building activities to improve the utilization of resilience knowledge for policy, programs and investments.  One of the coalition activities under the Collaborate function includes developing an internship programme dubbed the Global South Talent Pool, which includes capacity building, experience exchange and support to graduates and young experts from developing countries. This is one of the coalition’s activities aimed at making Global South demand and expertise take centre stage.  The coalition can run additional rounds based on demand and aligned to specific events and will promote the Global South internship modality among members and partners.

column5: Improving access to and use of actionable weather and early warning information for urban poor
column17: Early warning systems & early action
column31: Early warning systems (specific risk); Identify and take early actions
column174: Heat stress - lives & livelihoods combined; Extreme heat; Extreme cold; Urban flooding; Riverine flooding
column2775: DARAJA's action plan follows the pathway of codesigning/improving the weather and climate services which carries weather forecasts  and early warnings. DARAJA operates at multiple levels - at national level where we engage with national actors such as National  Meteorological Service; at city level where we engage with city authorities such as disaster management authority; at  community/settlement level where we engage with households directly and actors such as NGOs and CBOs. This approach impacts  the entire system and has a higher chance of improving a city's resilience.  As per the Theory of Change, DARAJA has four focus areas and follows that -  IF... WCIS (including early warnings) is relevant, understandable and useful; [PRODUCT]  and IF... WCIS is are provided at the right time, in the right format and through the most appropriate channels; [SERVICE]  and IF... The capacity of communities to be able to prepare for and to take actions to reduce the negative impacts of weather/ climate  events is strengthened; [ADAPTIVE CAPACITY]  and IF... Partnerships across urban-community systems are developed / strengthened to produce, disseminate and act upon WCIS  [SYSTEM]  THEN there will be... Reduced loss of life / improved livelihoods of vulnerable urban communities;  which leads to... Reduced climate vulnerability/ enhanced climate resilience.
column2781: Totally DARAJA is aiming for 30 cities. 13 cities are currently identified as priority cities where partners have been identified or discussions have started (including completed and ongoing). The rest will be identified over time/as per opportunities arise.
column2782: Each project is implemented as a consortium which has more than 2 organisations.
column2786: Some of the questions are not reflective of the way DARAJA is structured and operates, however, we have filled in the questions as  best as we could.  For instance, for the date when action will generate the expected impact on ALL intended beneficiaries and how long are you planning to keep delivering the action, we have selected 2030 as our plan is made to that year and thus expect all projects to have generated impact by then. However, each project under DARAJA will  have its own start and end dates; not all projects will be synchronous. E.g., two projects are already completed and have generated  impact. A third project is currently ongoing and will soon start to generate impact.  Similarly, the definitions of Enduring vs Fading benefits does not reflect the reality of DARAJA. We believe that DARAJA’s impacts  fade over time but not as soon as the project stops (as per the tool’s definition). Our first two projects’ cost-benefit analysis accounts  for fading over 5 years since the close of the project.
